channel.title: Hacking a Library Computer
channel.description:
There are a few computers at my library that I have to go to occasionally after school. I had to spend about an hour there the other day, and noticed that there is a little computer secluded in the back where I could mess around without anyone noticing me. It has connection to the Internet, but every time you try to go to an address that is outside of the library's server it automatically redirects you to the library's page.
After messing around for awhile I found a little wiggle room in the shitty locks in place. I was able to open Notepad through IE's "edit with notepad" option and save it as a .bat file which opened Command Prompt and got around the CMD block. I also got around their block on Windows Explorer by clicking a shortcut in the Help dialog box thing. I'm not sure if I would have access to the Registry, but my guess would be probably not as they blocked pretty much everything else.
My question: Would there be any way to unblock the Internet, make myself admin, something along those lines using IE, windows explorer, and CMD?

item.title: Hacking a Library Computer
item.dc:creator: @Quatrain Quatrain
item.description:
@Quatrain wrote:

Tried it on my home computer…

Read full topic

item.title: Hacking a Library Computer
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

[quote=“Quatrain, post:14, topic:327401”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=423790.msg3113210#msg3113210 date=1264718171]

It has connection to the Internet, but every time you try to go to an address that is outside of the library’s server it automatically redirects you to the library’s page.

It is probably accomplishing that using their own DNS server, if you set the computer to use opendns as the DNS server it will probably allow you full access to the internet.
[/quote]

Will that be possible with the Internet options blocked?[/quote]
Hence net user add, to create a local admin account.

Read full topic

item.description:
@Quatrain wrote:

It has connection to the Internet, but every time you try to go to an address that is outside of the library’s server it automatically redirects you to the library’s page.
[/quote]

It is probably accomplishing that using their own DNS server, if you set the computer to use opendns as the DNS server it will probably allow you full access to the internet.[/quote]

Will that be possible with the Internet options blocked?

Read full topic

item.title: Hacking a Library Computer
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Exactly as inertia said, it’s just a physical jumper on the mobo to reset the password/bios.

Read full topic

item.title: Hacking a Library Computer
item.dc:creator: @inertia inertia
item.description:
@inertia wrote:

[quote=“sanga282, post:10, topic:327401”][quote author=Unhandled link=topic=423790.msg3113130#msg3113130 date=1264715484]

where i work they don’t have BIOS passwords because they can be forgotten too easily

that is possibly the most fucking retarded reason for not having a password ever.
[/quote]
i dont run the joint i just work there, a few years before i started working there they did have BIOS passwords apparently but they had been forgotten it was a costly mistake so they havnt had them since[/quote]
ahahaha did they buy new mobos or something? all they had to do was activate the password/bios reset jumpers.

Read full topic

@moparisthebest wrote:

Quatrain:

It has connection to the Internet, but every time you try to go to an address that is outside of the library’s server it automatically redirects you to the library’s page.

It is probably accomplishing that using their own DNS server, if you set the computer to use opendns as the DNS server it will probably allow you full access to the internet.

item.title: Hacking a Library Computer
item.dc:creator: @sanga282 sanga282
item.description:
@sanga282 wrote:

[quote=“Unhandled, post:6, topic:327401”][quote author=sanga282 link=topic=423790.msg3113042#msg3113042 date=1264712916]

Just boot a live CD and do what the fuck you want?

HDD is probably given priority with a pass protecting any bios settings.

normally CD is given priority in case someone locks down the HDD or there’s an issue with booting, it works the same at educational institutes
[/quote]
if someone “locks down the HDD” or there’s a booting issue, the admins can enter the bios password and change the boot order…allowing just anyone to boot live cds in a really bad idea from an administrator’s perspective.[/quote]
where i work they don’t have BIOS passwords because they can be forgotten too easily

Read full topic

item.title: Hacking a Library Computer
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:

[quote=“sanga282, post:5, topic:327401”][quote author=inertia link=topic=423790.msg3112951#msg3112951 date=1264708463]

Just boot a live CD and do what the fuck you want?

HDD is probably given priority with a pass protecting any bios settings.
[/quote]
normally CD is given priority in case someone locks down the HDD or there’s an issue with booting, it works the same at educational institutes[/quote]
if someone “locks down the HDD” or there’s a booting issue, the admins can enter the bios password and change the boot order…allowing just anyone to boot live cds in a really bad idea from an administrator’s perspective.

Read full topic
